comment.author: 39229971@N08
comment._content: It has changed so much, and yet it has not changed at all.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: To start with Carlisle/O'Connell Bridge was widened between 1877 and 1880 so this predates the widening.  Secondly there's no sign of big Dan and most of the sculpture of the Street.  I'd better get Googling or whatever.  The foundation stone to Dan's monument was laid in 1864 but it was not completed unveiled until 1882.  I can't see any sign of a foundation stone here.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Construction of O'Connell Bridge started in 1877 (a big job), and the first tramline from the pillar to Drumcondra opened in 1877 too. So, 1877 at the latest.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Excellent! So before 1877, but also before 1864 as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] says: "I can't see any sign of a foundation stone here" ??

Earliest possible is 1860 for this series of photos...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
William Russell & Co. were at no. 5 Lower Sackville-Street, near Carlisle-bridge as early as Tuesday, 22 April 1851 as they have an advertisement in that day's Freeman's Journal declaring a reduction in the duty on coffee:
The Finest Mocha is now 1s. 6d. per pound. Costa Rica, Rio Janeiro, and fine Jamaice, 1s. 4d. per pound Demerara, Ceylon, and other imports, 8d., 10d., 1s., and 1s. 2d. per pound.
And Bewley & Evans were there too from at least November 1854 (also from Freeman's Journal).
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66841851@N00
comment._content: If this is from the 1860s the exposure time was potentially too long to capture moving people. It's why you often see deserted streets in photos from this time. Anything not nailed down is probably moving too fast to show up on the exposure.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I know it's not comparing like with like but looking at Google view there is no sign of either spire on view.  I must admit that I would be surprised if it were St. Georges as that is so far off to the east.

comment.author: 65379774@N02
comment._content: The long exposure has not captured any movement,hence the empty street or maybe the match was on.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here's one in the nli archive with Carlisle bridge and a tram, so later than this and very close to 1877. If [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] could take a closer look at that one in large, you might be able to see if there's any sign of the stone.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/boc] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65379774@N02] Take your point about exposure, however all the shops are closed and shuttered, and no signs of awnings...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] You can see the spire in this Google streetview image maps.google.ie/maps?q=o'connell+bridge&hl=en-GB&l... In my own mental map of the city I would have expected St George's to be much further east but if you look at the map it's actually pretty much on axis. Parnell Sq & North Frederick St cant off to the left (west) once you go past the top of O'Connell Street which is why the Abbey Church would not be visible (if indeed it was built at the time)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I'm pretty sure that is the Abbey Presbyterian church. here's a Streetview showing it peeking out from behind the Spire. Edit: No, I drove the Streetview car North up O'connell street, and this spire disappears to the right before the Abbey Church appears to the left. This is definitely St. Georges, and you wouldn't see the Abbey church from this angle even it it was built.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You can see the east street frontage of Parnell Sq East on that view and the Abbey church is on the west side of the street up to the left. Have a look at the map view and you'll see what I mean. maps.google.ie/maps?q=hardwicke+place,+dublin&hl=en-G...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That image is very weird - as if the negative has been cartoonised for display in a stereoscope. Problem is, it's the opposite of deserted, and crowds, carriages, etc. are masking the area around where stone would go. However, it looks as if the horse trough lamp is still there, now with the addition of side brackets for extra light...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You guys are both right and when you look at it in Streetview you can clearly see that it is St. Georges as it is a lighter colour portland stone and different shape to Abbey Church  Looking at the shot in question you can also see quite clearly the bending away to the left/west of Cavendish Row/Parnell Square West and North Frederick Street above it.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Metropole beside the GPO looked like that from 1860 to 1891, no help, although it was called the Prince of Wales in 1860.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Very interesting photo, I had a feeling the bridge was slightly out of position (pre-widening indeed). Unusual to see the street before the tram system had taken hold.

comment.author: 62294841@N07
comment._content: Why it is deserted - most probably a long exposure. It is a collodion wet-plate and to get that depth of field at those dates they were probably using a single meniscus Landscape lens stopped down (I'd say this is f64 or so) so the long exposure could be 10 mins+ which is why it looks deserted - there is  a bit of 'human mist' visible and some spectres - maybe carriages in the distance, quite blurred. Faster Rapid Rectilnear lenses did not appear until 1866 but a RR would also need to be stopped right down to achieve the great depth of field in this plate.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Probably combination of a quiet time of day (shop shutters closed) and a long exposure, there appears to be just a few carts moving in the distance (and some human mist), looks very surreal.

comment.author: 34574252@N02
comment._content:
A Foundation Stone [or Cornerstone] is a ceremonial stone usually laid by a dignitary and is above ground. It usually has some sort of inscription recording the event. 

The O'Connell one weighed about 2 tons and according to the report of the O'Connell monument committee ~ 

"The work was accomplished with an imposing ceremonial, on the 8th of August, 1864, by the Eight Hon. Peter Paul MacSwiney, Lord Mayor of Dublin, who undertook the duty of laying the foundation stone, at the special request of the O'Connell Monument Committee".

[At 3:30pm he used] "a trowel of beautiful workmanship, composed entirely of solid silver, and bearing the following inscription : — 

Presented by THE COMMITTEE OP THE O CONNELL NATIONAL MONUMENT  to the 
Right Hon. Peter Paul M'Swiney, Lord Mayor of Dublin, On the occasion of his laying the first stone of the Monument"

comment.author: 66151649@N02

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Street listings for the right side of the street from 1862, www.libraryireland.com/Dublin-Street-Directory-1862/137.php 3 & 4 Bewley & Evans, apothecaries and chemists to the Queen and Lord Lieutenant, each 110l. ,, Brewis, William John, manager for Messrs. Bewley and Evans ,, Hamilton, John T. M.D. of the firm of Bewley, Evans, and Co. 5 New East India Tea Company, 105l. ,, Russell, Wm. & Co. grocers, tea, wine, and spirit merchants ,, Russell, William, esq. J.P. Cathe- rine's-park, Rathfarnham

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] Yup. Bewley & Evans are listed on the 1862 directory at 3 & 4 Lower Sackville st. By the time the 1868 directory is written the listing for the same address is "Hamilton Bewley and Co" (also a chemist/apothecary but mainly selling "Mineral, Soda Water, and Ginger Beer"). What the yanks would've called a drugstore. Some nice pics here of their contemporary product lines: (Info only really. Doesn't refine the dates any further).
